awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The role of eddies in the propagation and dissipation of wind-driven near-inertial energy: a numerial study bridging OGCM and process simulations
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will examine how energy from wind forcing of the ocean propagates into the ocean interior and dissipates. The methods used include combining different types of numerical models to examine the detailed physical processes governing wind forced near-inertial wave energy in the presence of ocean eddies. The study also includes collaboration with French researchers to make comparisons with and analyze observations from the LAgrangian Transport Experiment (LATEX). The results will be useful for developing improved physical representations of mixing processes in climate ocean models. Results will be disseminated to the scientific community through presentations at conferences and scientific publications. The project will support one undergraduate student in summer research.

While the role of anticyclonic eddies in fluxing near-inertial energy into the deep ocean has long been established observationally, theoretically and numerically, the fate of this energy once it leaves the mixed layer remains unconstrained. Observations at depths remain relatively sparse. The proposed research will use numerical modeling and analysis of observational data to explore interactions between eddies and near-inertial waves and determine the dissipation processes for wind-driven near-inertial waves (NIW) in the presence of mesoscale eddies. A Boussinesq model with high vertical resolution and non-hydrostatic dynamics will be nested in a regional circulation model (NEMO-GLAZUR64) to provide realistic forcing and boundary conditions. The model results will be compared with data from the LATEX experiment in the Gulf of Lyon.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Wind blowing over the surface of the ocean produces near-inertial oscillations, i.e. oscillations with a frequency set by the Earth's rotation and latitude. A fraction of these oscillations remains near the surface in a layer called the mixed layer and another fraction acquires a frequency slightly above the inertial frequency and propagates out of the mixed layer into the deep ocean.  Once they leave the mixed layer, these oscillations can propagate and are called near-inertial waves. Like the familiar surface waves on the ocean, these waves can break and dissipate energy but they differ from surface waves in their much slower speeds and they can propagate vertically as well as horizontally. Anticyclonic mesoscale eddies exist on scales of order 100km. They can trap wind-generated near-inertial waves and they have been shown to provide them with a preferential pathway into the deep ocean.


Numerical models that are used to study near-inertial waves provide information on small length scales (typically 10s of meters to 10km) but including the range of length and time scales characteristic of mesoscale eddies would be prohibitively expensive. Alternatively, models called eddy-resolving general circulation models are useful for studying the evolution of larger length scales (typically 100s of kms) but they cannot model the small vertical lengths that are typical of near-inertial waves. An accurate understanding of the fate of near-inertial waves in the presence of mesoscale eddies therefore requires a model that encompasses both large and small scales.

To circumvent this problem, our project has consisted of nesting a small-scale model inside a larger-scale model dataset using a novel mathematical algorithm. The large-scale model information is communicated through the boundaries of the smaller-scale model. Therefore, our small-scale model solutions do not evolve independently of the larger scales but are influenced by them. To analyze our results, we resort to a diagnostic model that separates waves and eddies. This diagnostic tool enables us to probe the complex interactions between near-inertial waves and eddies.


Intellectual Merit: The nesting technique has enabled us to simultaneously incorporate the effects of mesoscale eddies on near-inertial oscillations while zooming in on the intricate behavior of near-inertial waves as they propagate into the deep ocean. The nested domain simulations exhibit richer kinetic energy spectra at depth in the superinertial frequency regime. We also find that wave energy is funnelled out of the mixed layer preferentially in anticyclonic eddies.


 Broader impacts: This project provided a research topic for an undergraduate summer intern at the University of Washington. A masters student in Spain also participated in this project but received no funding. The project benefited an early-career woman scientist Dr. Mariona Claret. The PI has been a mentor with MPOWIR (Mentoring Physical Oceanography Women to Increase Retention) since 2020.
